statement.text: Recurrent carotid stenosis occurs in 5-10% of patients after CEA, categorized as early (myointimal hyperplasia, <2 years) or late (recurrent atherosclerosis, >2 years), with treatment typically by CAS given surgical scarring.

explanation.intuition: Just as some people form thick scars on their skin, some form excessive scar tissue inside their arteries after surgery. Early restenosis is this exuberant healing response; late restenosis is the disease coming back.
explanation.key_insight: Early restenosis (<2 years) is due to myointimal hyperplasia which is generally stable and rarely causes stroke. Late restenosis (>2 years) is recurrent atherosclerosis with higher stroke risk. CAS is often preferred for recurrent stenosis due to scarring.
explanation.technical_details: Incidence: 5-10% significant restenosis post-CEA. Early (<2 years): myointimal hyperplasia - smooth, stable, low embolic risk. Late (>2 years): recurrent atherosclerosis - irregular, higher embolic risk. Treatment indications: similar to primary stenosis. Treatment options: CAS preferred (avoids surgical scarring), redo CEA technically challenging. Risk factors for restenosis: female sex, smoking, patch vs primary closure (lower with patch).

clinical_pearls: Early restenosis (<2 years) is hyperplasia - usually stable, low stroke risk
Late restenosis (>2 years) is recurrent atherosclerosis - higher stroke risk
CAS preferred for recurrent disease due to surgical scarring
